Sub: Assessment of Roof Structure and Canopy Designs at Airports: Reg.

It is informed that 03 incidents of roof structure/canopy collapses following
heavy rain and water logging at airports namely Jabalpur, Delhi and Rajkot were
reported in the month of June 2024. The incidents significantly disrupted airport
operations, leading to delays in flights, cancellations and overall operational
inefficiencies. It also created hazardous conditions, resulting in damage to property
and a life also

2. Considering the incidents, on request of DGCA, IIT Delhi had carried out a
detailed investigation into the incident at IGI airport. The findings, outlined in the
enclosed IIT Delhi report, highlight various discrepancies and issues related to the
infrastructure design, fabrication, execution and maintenance. The possible
contributory factors in the roof collapse have been identified as under

Inferior workmanship in fabrication and execution, particularly welded
connections.

+ The service loads as well as live loads considered in the design of roof canopy
structures seem to be on the lower side.

+ The detailing and design of connections, particularly welding connections, have
not been carried out adequately. In absence of any documents, it appeared that
this important aspect was left to the fabricators for their own
interpretation/execution.

+ Incessant rain caused an accumulation of water on the roof, and the capacity of
the welded connection was finally breached. The load may have increased
during rain due to drain backflow or waterlogging or a combination. Once the fin
plate weld connection failed, the structure experienced sequential failure of
different structural elements.
2:
3

Weld connections being brittle did not give enough warning and chances to
escape before its failure

Periodic inspections and maintenances are necessary to prevent their failure
due to corrosion or any such effects.

Additionally, IIT Delhi has made the following recommendations for the roof

structures:

4

A thorough inspection and investigation by a specialized agency is
recommended

In particular, all connections, welding, etc. shall be checked thoroughly. The
structural design and detailing are required to be checked thoroughly in
accordance with current code provisions and actual site conditions. If required
necessary retrofitting measures should be implemented through specialized
agencies

All connections and components essential for the load transfer mechanism
should he looked into and retrofitted by the specialized agency, if required

Stub plates to support the purlins require assessment. It is not a suitable
structural element for taking the loads

Drainage design shall be investigated for adequacy/inadequacy. Necessary
modifications for example provision of suction devices in the drain, overflow
mechanism, perforated false ceiling near drains, etc. may be required to remove
the water stagnation in case of incessant rain events.

In view of the above, | have been directed to request all DisG and CASOs of

ASGs to coordinate and actively pursue the matter with the respective airport
operators to expedite implementation of the necessary measures and actions based
on the suggestions outlined by IIT Delhi

5.

This is issued with the approval of the Competent Authority.

Encl. as above.

lnterpretations and observations
The assessment of the collapsed portion was canied out based on these documents received,
and the response of DGCA/DIAL on 29-07 -2024 clarifling the details related to the city-side
collapsed portion ofthe roof. The failure ofa structure may be due to several factors associated
with the analysis and design, fabrication, execution, or maintenance. Therefore, all possible
aspects of various stages were studied for completeness. The observations are noted in the
following sections.
(a) Study of submitted design and analysis data
The team studied the design basis report (DBR), drawings, analysis files, etc., and found some
inconsistencies as Iisted below:
l. DBR 1. Page 35: Considered seismic loads are as per zolle v (2:0.36). importance factor
(f as 1.5, and response reduction factor (R) as 4. Response spectra referred for hard soil
conditions. tn the very next section of the DBR, it is mentioned that soil conditions
correspond to medium, However, analysis files, namely, STAAD Input file l: G-l266-5-
026-R2 and STAAD input file 2: G-1266-5-027-R0 (listed in the first set ofdocuments) on
page 2 mention that the soil considered was "soft soil" and the value ofresponse reduction
factor (R) was taken as 5. This may result in diflerent force demands for the main skuch:ral
members than those considered in the desigrl. However, this may not be the primary cause
ofthe collapse ofthe roof canopy on 28-06-2024.
2. In the First set of documents, it was mentioned that the live load considered for the curved
roofrvas 0.5 kpa. This is not consistent with the provisions ofrelated Indian Standards. As
per IS: 875 (Part 2) (ref. Tabte 2), the value ofthe imposed load should have been 0.75 kPa
instead of 0.5 kPa considered in the analysis. Also, IS 875 (Part 2) (ref. Clause 4.3, Table
2) mentions that if the accumulation of rainwater is possible on the rooi more critical of
the imposed load and accumulated rainwater should be considered in the analysis. Neither
the DBR nor the analysis considered the critical load of these. Therefore' the design
demand on the roofs structural members and connections may have been underestimated.

3. Services load considered in the analysis was 20 kg/sqm (i.e., 0.3 kN/m on the purlins for a
tributary of 1.5 m) as per STAAD lnput file l- G-1266-5-026-R2 and STAAD input file 2
G-1266-5-02'7 -R0 (listed in the first set of documents). However, in DBR 1 (page 35), it is
mentioned that the service load should be 1.5 kPa including fatse ceiling loads.
Accordingly, the load on purlins would be computed as 2.25 kN/m for a spacing of 1.5 m.
Thus, the loads considered in the design do not match the data mentioned in the DBR.
4. The purlin size mentioned in File no. 12 (513-A), which is an as-built drawing as mentioned
in the title box), is l80x I 80x6, resting directly on the top chords. The fifth set ofdocuments
shows that the purlin sizes are 180x180x7 and l80xl80x5 (NTIB - Drawings). Fabrication
Drawing*1-039 in the fourth set of documents shows that the purlin sizes are l80xl80x6
and 180x180x4. There is an inconsistency in the member sizes considered in the design
and fabrication.
5. Drawing Fabrication Drawing_l-037, in rhe fourth set of documents, shows the sizes of
flared columns and tie members as NB400H. Drawing Fabrication Drawing_l-300, in the
same set of documents, shows different markings for the flared columns and tie members
(TC4, TC5, TC13, and so on). In the fifth set of documents (NTIB - Drawings), these
members are mentioned as NB450x6.3, NB450xl2, and so on. The second set of
documents shows these members as CHS457x6.3, CHS 406.5x6.3, and so on. In the third
set ofdocuments (File no. 57 & 59), which are labeled as as-built drawings, flared columns
are NB450Hx6.3 and NB450Hxl2 same as in the analysis. Tie members are mentioned as
NB400Hx7 and NB450Hxl2, which are N8400x6.3 and NB450xi2 in the analysis. There
is a mismatch in the member sizes in different submitted drawings. The Client confirmed
the flared columns as CITCI3/CITCI3X and tie members as CICTl2 tkough the
document "Response to Queries to IIT Delhi" towards the collapsed portion of the roof.
6. From the analysis, vertical reactions for Dead Loads, Service Loads, and Imposed Loads
are 23659 kN, 3756 kN, and 9386 kN, respectively. Considering 2=0.36, I:l.5, R:5, and
SJg:2.5 (for an expected time period of the building less than 0.5 sec), the horizontal
seismic force coefficient, lr, is 0.135. Seismic weight, I/ is computed to be 27415 kN,
ignoring the imposed loads from the roof. Accordingly, seismic base shear should be in the
range of3700 kN. However, in the analysis, seismic base shear in both horizontal directions
is 2256 kN. This means that a smaller lateral seismic force has been considered for the
design of the roof structure than that envisaged in DBR.

7. Further, ifthe value ofR is taken as 4 (or 5), the design and detailing of roof tmss members
should have been carried out to ensure sufficient ductility (through a capacity-based design
approach) in order to protect the failure ofjoints. Such calculations are either not avarlable
or not submitted to the Committee. Therefore, it is not clear whether this aspect was ever
considered at the design stage.
(b) Discrepancies in fabricatlons
The following discrepancies/issues were observed regarding the fabrications.

photographinFigurel'Thisisquitepossiblethatthesechangesmighthavebeencarried
out during the execution. However, the same has neither been shown in the as-built
drawings, nor any calculations supporting the strength and stability of these plates. In
addition, the fabrication shows poor workmanship at few places'

(c) Observations on executions/workmanship
11. As observed at the site (Figure 1). the welding, connection detailing, etc., appears to be of
inferior workmanship at some locations.
12. Fin plate weld penetration seems to be inadequate as in the failure photograph in Figure 3.
The thickness of the fin plate welded to the flared columns towards the city side is 60 mm,
as given in the drawings. Usually, for such highthickness plate welding, the fabricator
should have employed a proper methodology to ensure full penetration of the weld. Here,
based on the failure photographs, it seems that the fuIl penetration weld was not achieved.

and the false ceiling didn't have fireproof paint and anti-corrosion measures in the

(a) Analysis results and probable causes of the collapse
There could be multiple factors attributing to the collapse ofthe roof strucrure. The sequence
of the events was established based on the documents provided by the Client, the response to
the queries by the Client, and the CCTV footage received.
with the discrepancies/issues in the design, fabrication, exccution, and maintenance highrighted
in the preceding sections, the question was why did the roofco apse on that day after a period

5. 
Mainfindings/recommendations
15:
of more than 15 years of its construction. The argument may be placed if simply not meeting
the design requirements would result in a collapse ofa structure when it may not be subjected
to the critical combinations of loads of destgned magnitudes' It is true that the members may
not fail (or collapse) in such cases due to inherent overstrength and redundancies. However, if
the detailing of critical members and connections is not properly carried out during the
fabrication and execution, it may lead to complete collapse if some loads reach or exceed their
design values in some situations-
In order to understand the root cause of failure, the analysis results were studied. In general, the
sizes of the main members of the truss were found to be satisfactory. However, no
documents/calculations were made available to the committee to ascertain whether the design
of connections was adequate or not- Therefore, the critical members and connections were
studiedindetail(basedontheanalysis,sitevisits,andCCTVfootage)'Inthiscase'theflared
columns supporting t-Ile trusses were found to be critical for causing the failure of the truss
canopy.
Figure6showstlletypicalsketchofthetreecolurnnstructuresupportingthetrussestowards
the city side. Rooftrusses rest over the two flared columns having their ends spaced at l5 rn. A
horizontal tie member is connected, as shown in Figure 6. using fin plate pin connections
welded on the flared columns. Even if discrepancies were observed in the analysis models
submitted, the original results were considered at the initial stage to investigate the force
demand ol the members and connections of this column structure'
It is interesting to note that the analysis and design were carried out for the model wherein the
horizontal tie member (shown in Figure 6) was placed at the top free ends of both flared
columns. However, the drawings and site photographs show that the horizontal tie member was
connected to the flared column at an intermediate level below the top ends ofthe flared columns
(see Figure 6). This would result in a different force transfer path and different force demand
on the welding between the fin plate and the members

Fromtheaboveanalysis,itcanbeconcludedthatthecollapseoflheroofwasprimarilydueto
thefailureoftheweldinthefinconnectionoftlrehorizontaltiememberofatreecolumn.Most
of the welds were not properly executed as can be seen in the failure photographs Further'
incessant rain on the day was the final trigger' as the water accurnulation led to the final roof
collapse. The location ofthe gutter was also near the failed portion of the roof' The load may

(a) Possible contributory factors:
Strong possibility ofbrittle weld cracking due to highry stressed and inferior quarity werd. In
all probability, a full cross-sectional area in the weld zone was not available, and it was only
35-45 mm available thickness. Approximately 70-g0 mm of water depth was sufficient to take
the stresses in the weld base ofthe fin to the yield point, causing connection failure. The same
is also correlated with the CCTV footage made available by the Client.
Possible contributory factors in the roofcolapse may be summarized as foflows:
l. Inferior workmanship in fabrication and execution, particularly welded
connections.
2' As mentioned in points 2 and 3 in the section ..Interpretations and observations',,
the service loads as well as live loads considered in the design of roof canopy
structures seem to be on the lower side.
3' The detairing and design ofconnections, particularry wetding connections, have not
been carried out adequatery. In absence of any documents, it appeared that this
important aspect was reft to the fabricators for their own interpretation/execution.
4' Incessant rain caused an accumulation of water on the roof, and the capacity of the
welded connection was finary breached. The road may have increased during rain
due to drain backflow or waterlogging or a combination. once the fin prate weld
connection failed, the
structural elements,
structure experienced sequential failure of different
Weld connections being brittle did not give enough warning and chances to escape
before its failure.
6' Though the main members are found to be adequate in size, periodic inspections
and maintenances are necessarv to prevent their failure due to corrosion or any
such effects.

The following recommendations are made for the non_collapsed roof structure:
1' A thorough inspection and investigation by a speciarized agency is recommended.
2' In particular, all connections, werding, etc. shalr be checked thoroughty. The
structural design and detailing are required to be checked thoroughly in

Method Statement for
Supporting Existing Structure and Removal of Damaged Structure
8. Removal of False Ceiling (At required Location)
Assess the Area: Use a TVEWP to access the area near the edge of the last grid of the false ceiling
where Ceiling Support is located. Ensure the lift is positioned safely and securely.
Remove AcP support: once in position, carefully remove the ACp support that is part of the false
ceiling structure. This may involve unscrewing or detaching the supports depending on how they are
fixed.
Remove False Ceiling Panels: After removing the ACP supports, proceed to remove the false ceiling
panels.
Prepare for Gas Gutting: once the false ceiling panels are removed, assess the ceiling structure. lf
there are metal elemenls or supports that need to be removed, prepare for gas cutting.
Gas Cutting Procedure: Use gas cutting equipment to carefully cut through any metal elements that
need to be removed as part of the false ceiling structure. Ensure all safety protocols for gas cutting
are followed, including proper ventilation and fire safety measures.
Dispose of Materials: As you progress, dispose of removed materials (such as panels and metal
supports) in designated areas.
safety Protocol: Throughout the process, prioritize safety. Ensure all workers involved in gas
curting are trained and equipped with appropriate personal protective equipment (ppE).

7. Removal of Skin :
stabilization of Structure: Ensure adequate support at the bottom of the truss to srabilize the
structure during the removal process. This is crucial for safety and to prevent structural damage.
Safe Access for Manpower: Provide safe access for workers to move above the roof. This typically
involves setting up ladders or scaffolding lo access the roof safely.
Fall Arrest System: lnstall retractable fall arrestors/MEWP ensures that workers are protected from
falls while working at heights.
Removal of rop Layer: Use gas cufting or a cutting wheer to remove the top rayer of roof sheeting.
Ensure that all safety precautions are followed during this cutting process.
Lowering Removed Sheets: After the sheets are cut, lower them safely by sliding them over the
existing roof uslng PP (Polypropylene) ropes. This method helps in controlled desceni of the removed
materials.
lnsulation Removal: Once the top roof sheeting is removed, proceed with the removal of insulation
material.
Subsequent Layer Removal: Remove subsequent layers of materials to expose the top roof truss.
This step involves systematically removing any remaining layers of insulation or sheeting until the
truss is fully exposed.
safety Protocol: Throughout the entire process, prioritize safety byensuring allworkers are equipped
with appropriate personar protective equipment (ppE) and are trained in safety procedures.
By following these steps systematically and with a focus on safety, the removal of roof sheeting with
insulation can be done efficienfly while minimizing risks to personnel and property.

Assessment and PreParation: Evaluate the truss Structure to be removed and plan the cutting

are in good working condition.
Gutting procedure: start cutting the truss structure into small, manageable pieces using gas cutting
equipmint. Begin from the free end of the truss and work towards the fagade of the structure' No
Personnel will be u allowed undemeath lhe structure
controlled Removal: As each section of the truss is cut, carefully lower or remove it from the
structure. Use cranes, hoists, or other lifting equjpment as necessary to safely handle and transport
the cut pieces.
Monitoring and cleanup: Throughout the process, monitor the stability of the remaining structure
and ensure there are no unforesin hazards. Clean up debris and maintain a clear workspace for
ongoing activities.
completionandlnspection:oncealltrusssectionsareremoved,inspecttheareatoconfirmthat
the removal is complete, and the site is safe for further construction
safety protocol: Maintain a safe distance from the cutting operation and ensure proper ventilation
to dissipate gases and fumes generated by gas cutting. Use protective gear such as gloves, goggles,
and fire-resistant clothing.
By following these steps systematically and emphasizing safety throughout the process' you can
effectively remove truss structures using gas cutting, ensuring the project progresses smoothly and
safely.
